projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2007-07 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2007-09 Emma (Leeson) HuberText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: THE SONGS IN THE Indian QUEEN: As it is now Compos'd into an OPERA. By Mr. HENRY PURCELL, Compoer in Ordinary to his Majety. And one of the Organits of his Majety's Chapel-Royal.

LONDON, Printed by J. Heptintall; and are to be Sold by John May, at his Shop under St. Duntan's Church: And for John Hudgbutt at Tho. Dring's, Bookeller, at the Harrow at Clifford's-lane-end in Fleettreet. 1695.

div.head: The Publihers, to Mr. Henry Purcell.
div.p: HAving had the good Fortune to meet with the Score or Original Draught of your Incomparable Eay of Muick compos'd for the Play, call'd The Indian Queen. It oon appear'd that we had found a Jewel of very great Value; on which account we were unwilling that o rich a Treaure hould any longer lie bury'd in Oblivion; and that the Common-wealth of Muick hould be depriv'd of o coniderable a Benefit. Indeed we well knew your innate Modety to be uch, as not to be eaily prevail'd upon to et forth any thing in Print, much les to Patronize your own Works, although in ome repects Inimitable. But in regard that (the Pres being now open) any one might print an imperfect Copy of thee admirable Songs, or publih them in the nature of a Common Ballad, We were o much the more emboldned to make this Attempt, even without acquainting you with our Deign; not doubting but your accutomed Candor and Generoity will induce you to pardon this Preumption: As for our parts, if you hall think fit to condecend o far, we hall always endeavour to approve our elves,

closer.signed: Your Obedient Servants, J. May, J. Hudgebutt.

div.head: A Song in the firt Act, Sung by Mr. Freeman.
div.p:
<> WAke, <>
<> wake, wake Qui—
<>
<>
—-ve—ra, wake, our oft————ret mut <>
<> ceae; wake, wake, <>
<> wake, Qui—ve—ra, wake,—our <>
<> oft—————ret mut ceae, and fly—-—to—gether, <>
<> and fly————————to—ge—ther <>
<> with our Country's peace; no <>
<> more, no more, no more, no more, no more, no more, no more, no more, no,——no <>
<> more mut we leep, mut we leep under Plan——tain hade, which neither <>
<> Heat could peirce, nor Cold in-vade; where bount'ous Nature never, never, never, <>
<> never, never, never feels de-cay, and op'-—ning Buds, and op'—ning <>
<> Buds drive——fall—-——-——ing Fruits a—way. <>

div.head: A Song in the firt Act, Sung by the Boy with Flutes.
div.p:
<> WHY, <>
<> why, why hou'd men quarrel, why, why hou'd men quarrel here, where all, <>
<> all, all, where all———po—es as much as they can hope for <>
<> by uc—ces; none, none can have mot none can have mot, where <>
<> Nature is o kind, as to ex-ceed, as to ex—cee———— <>
<> —-d <> Man's u •• tho' not his Mind; why, why, <>
<> why hou'd Men quarrel, why, why hou'd Men quarrel here, where all, all, <>
<> all, where all————po—es as much as they can hope for <>
<> by uc-ces, as much as they can hope for by uc——ces, <>
<> as much as they can hope, as much as they can hope for by uc—ces. <>

l.hi: By antient Prophecyes we have been told,
Our Land hall be ubdu'd by one more old,
And ee that world's already hither come,
If thee be they, we welcome then our doom.

div.head: A Song Sung by Mr. Freeman.
div.p:
<> THeir looks are uch that Mercy flow—————-—s <>
<> from thence, more gen—tle, gen—tle than our Na-—tive in—nocence: <>
<> By their pro—tec—tion let us, let us, let us beg to live, they come not <>
<> here to con—quer but for—give; by their pro—tec—tion let us, let us, <>
<> let us beg to live, they come not here to con—quer but for— <>
<> —give, they come not here to con—quer but for—give. <>

l.hi: If o your goodnes may your power expres,
And we hall judge both bet by our Succes.

div.head: A Song in the Second Act, Sung by Mr. Freeman.
div.p:
<> I come to Sing great Zem———po—al-la's to—ry, whoe beaut'ous ight, o <>
<> Charming bright, out-hines the Lu—tre of glory; whoe beaut'ons ight, o <>
<> charming bright, out—hines the Lu—tre of glo-ry. <>
div.stage: Sung by Envy and his followers with-Intruments.

lg.l: What Flat'ring noie is this,
At which my Snakes all his;
I hate to ee fond Tongues advance,
High as the Gods, the laves of Chance.

div.head: A Song Sung by Mr. Freeman.
div.p:
<> SCorn'd Envy here's nothing, here's nothing that thou, that thou cant blat; Her <>
<> glo—ries, her glo—ries are too bright, to be o'er— <>
<> ——cat; her glo—ries, her glo—ries are too brigh——— <>
<> —t to be o'er—-cat. <>
div.stage: Sung by Envy and his followers with Intruments.

lg.l: I fly from the place where Flaterry reigns,
See thoe mighty things that before,
Such laves like Gods did adore,
Contemn'd and unpitty'd in Chains.

div.head: A Song Sung by Mr. Freeman.
div.p:
<> BE—gone, begone, be—gone curt Feinds of Hell, ink down, ink <>
<> down where Noiome Vapers dwell; While I, while I her <>
<> tri———————-—-—umph ound, <>
Turn over.
<> while I, while I her Try————————— <>
<> ——umph ound, to fill, to fill the U—ni—ver—al Round. <>

lg.l: YOu twice ten hundred Deities,
To whom we daily Sacrifice;
Ye Powr's that dwell with Fates below,
And ee what Men are doom'd to doe;
Where Elements in Dicord dwell,
Thou God of Sleep, arie, and tell,
Great Zempoalla what trange Fate,
Mut on her dimall Viion wait.

lg.head: The Conjurer's Charm.
lg.l: BY the Croaking of the Toad,
In their Caves that make abode;
Earthy Dun that pants for breath,
With her well'd ides full of death;
By the Creted Adder's Pride,
That along the Cliffs do glide;
By the Viage fierce and black,
By the death's Head on thy back;
By the twited Serpents plac'd,
For a Girdle round thy Wate;
By the Hearts of Gold that deck,
Thy Breat, thy Shoulders, and thy Neck;
From thy leeping Manion rie,
And open thy unwilling Eyes;
While bubling Springs their Muick keep,
That ue to lull thee in thy leep.

div.stage: Sung by the God of Dreams.

lg.l: SEek not to know, what mut not be reveal'd,
Joys only flow where Fate is mot conceal'd;
Too buy Man would find his Sorrows more,
If future Fortune He hou'd know before;
For by that knowledge of his Detiny,
He wou'd not live at all, but always dye;
Enquire not then who hall from Bonds be freed,
Who 'tis hall wear a Crown, and who hall bleed;
All mut ubmit to their appointed doom,
Fate and Misfortunes will too quickly come;
Let me no more with powerfull Charms be pret,
I am forbid by Fate to tell the ret.

div.head: A Song in the Third Act, Sung by Mr. Freeman, and Mr. Church.
div.p:
<> AH!—ah!—how hap-py are we, are we, are <> Ah!—ah!—ah! how hap—py are we, are we, <>
<> we, ah! ah! how hap-py are we, from humane paions, from humane <> are we, ah! ah! how hap-py are we, from humane <>
<> paions free: <> paions free: <>
<> ah! ah! ah! ah! how hap—py are <> ah!—ah!—ah!—how hap—py are <>
<> we, thoe wil—————————— <> we, thoe wil—————————— <>
<> —-—d Tenants of the Breat; no never, never, no never, never, no never, <> ——d Tenants of the Breat; no never, never, no never, <>
<> never, never can diturb our ret; ah!— <> never, never can diturb our ret; ah!—ah!— <>
<> ah! how hap—py are we, are we, are we, ah! ah! how <> ah! how hap—py are we, are we, are we, ah! ah! how <>
<> happy are we: Yet we pit—ty, we pit—ty, we <> happy are we: Yet we pit—ty, we <>
<> pitty, tender Souls whom the Tyrant Love, whom the Tyrant Love, whom the Tyrant <> pitty, tender Souls whom the Tyrant Love, whom the Tyrant Love, whom the <>
<> Love con—trouls; ah! ah! how <> Tyrant Love con—trouls; ah! ah! ah! how <>
<> happy are we from humane Paion, from humane Pa———— <> happy are we, from humane Pa———— <>
Turn over.
<> ————————————ion free. <> ———-—————————ion free. <>

div.head: A Song Sung by Mrs. Cros.
div.p:
<> I Attempt from Love's icknes to fly———in vain, ince I am <>
<> my elf my own Feaver, ince I am my elf my own Feaver and Pain; No <>
<> more now, no more now fond Heart with Pride, no more well, thou can't not raie <>
<> Forces, thou can't not raie Forces enough to re—bell:Firt train again. For <>
<> Love has more pow'r and les mercy than fate, to make us eek ru—in, <>
<> to make us eek ru—ine, and love thoe that hate. End with the firt Strain
<>

sp.speaker: Vers. Then Cho.
sp.l: We the Spirits of the Air,
That of Humane Things take Care,
Out of Pity now decend,
To forewarn what Woes attend;

sp.speaker: Vers.
sp.l: Greatnes clogg'd with Scorn decays,
With the Slave no Empire tay's,

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: We the Spirits &c.

sp.speaker: Vers.
sp.l: Ceae to languih then in vain,
Since never to be lov'd again.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: We the Spirits, &c.

div.head: A Song in the Fourth Act, Sung by Mrs. Cros.
div.p:
<> THey tell us that you migh—ty Powers a—bove, make perfect your <>
<> Joys and your bleings by Love; Ah! why do you fuffer, ah! <>
<> why do you uf-fer the bleing that's there; to give a poor Lover uch <>
Turn over.
<> ad torments here, yet tho' for my pa-—ion uch greif I en—dure, <>
<> my love hall like yours till be con—tant and pure. <>

lg.head: II.
lg.l: To uffer for him gives an eae to my pains,
There's joy in my grief, and there's freedom in Chains.
If I were divine he cou'd love me no more,
And I in return my adorer adore;
Oh! let his dear life then (kind Gods) be your care,
For I in your bleings have no other hare.

div.head: A Sacrifice, Sung by the Chief Priet.
div.l: WHile thus we bow before your Shrine,
That you may hear great Powers Divine,
All living things hall in your Praies joyne;
You who at the Altars tand,
The fatal Word hall oon be hear'd,

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: —All's prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Priet.
sp.l: Let all unhallow'd Souls be gone,
Before our Sacred Rites come on,
Take care that this be alo done,

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: —All is done.

sp.speaker: Priet.
sp.l: Now in proceion walk along,
And then begin your olemn Song.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: All dimal ounds thus on this Offering wait,
Your power's hown by their untimely Fate;
While by uch various Fate's we learn to know,
There's nothing to be truted here below.

div.p: BOOKS Printed for, and Sold by John Hudgebutt.
A Collection of New A • RS, Compoed for Two Flutes with Sonata's, by everal of the mot Ingenious Maters of this Age. Price One Shilling Sixpence.

At John May's Shop under St. Duntans-Church in Fleettreet, you may have all New Songs, and Sets of AIRS that's Sung or Play'd at either of the Theatres, fairly Writ-out for any Intrument, and all other Muical-Goods.
